data.title: AASI Intermountain » Snowboard DECL Team
data.meta_description: Professional Snowsports Instruction in the Intermountain West
data.text:
How did you get your start in this career field? Working for small concession ski club at Snoqualmie Pass, WA. Basically lived on the floor of the lodge every weekend for 6 years and loved every minute of it!

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? I just keep pursuing my interest, which has turned out to be facilitating professional and personal growth for individuals in various environments.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Living in another country.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? How many different ways the skills developed in this industry transfer into other professional and personal pursuits.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? Don’t stress over things you can’t control. Focus on what you can control, even if it’s incredibly limited, and build from there.

Please list your hidden talent(s): I am good at snapping awake and being able to instantly make decisions, a forced skill from my road trip guiding days.

Originally From: San Francisco, CA

Years Instructing: 22

Favorite Skier or Snowboarder: Tina Basich

Why do you work in the ski industry? Love growing my passion for snowboarding and sharing that passion to inspire others

What else do you do besides skiing/snowboarding? Ski resort marketing, kid raising, river rafting

If you could have dinner with anyone, dead or alive, who would it be and why? My grandmother—to hear more of her stories, taste more of her cooking, feel more of her presence.

Originally From: Summit Valley, WA

Years Instructing: 24

Favorite Skier or Snowboarder: The fun ones

Why do you work in the ski industry? I have stayed in this industry to continue spreading the love of being in the snow.

What else do you do besides skiing/snowboarding? I ride Hardenduro, Moto, Engin Wrechi’n, Mountain Bike Oh and go to the gym.

If you could have dinner with anyone, dead or alive, who would it be and why? Rudolf Diesel! Because he rivals Edison in the engineering of the modern world

How did you get your start in this career field? I took a gap year from school and worked for a ski school in upstate NY, and then went to New Zealand that summer to participate in an instructor training course called Rookie Academy.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? The trainers I had during my first year of instructing inspired me to follow their path. It was way more fun and cheaper than college tuition!

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Stand up comedy.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? The variety of people who are drawn to instruction always impresses me. Ski schools are like melting pots for culture.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? How to seek and accept feedback.

Please list your hidden talent(s): I’m ambidextrous with chopsticks.

How did you get your start in this career field? Needed a job during the winter when I graduated high school and have done it ever since.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? Love of the sport.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Rally car driver.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? The community is amongst fellow instructors.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? That you can make a living while doing something you love.

Please list your hidden talent(s): I was a clogger in high school, my high school band had a song in a movie.

How did you get your start in this career field? I needed a pass.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? I love being in the mountains.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Wing surfing.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? That I love to teach.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? To not compare myself to others.

Please list your hidden talent(s): I can extract toothpaste from an empty tube. I can cut my own hair. I can guess what people are thinking.

Originally From: Rocky Mountain

Years Instructing: 13

Favorite Skier or Snowboarder: Max Parrot

Why do you work in the ski industry? Share the love, bring snowsports to everyone, the more people you teach means the more friends you have on the mountain.

What else do you do besides skiing/snowboarding? Snowboard, rock climb, and mountain bike

If you could have dinner with anyone, dead or alive, who would it be and why? I think it would be really fun to have dinner with someone like Jimmy Chin, he’s probably got some stories and knowledge to share.

How did you get your start in this career field? Friend recommendation.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? Getting to work with and see the progression with Winter Sports enthusiasts.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Hang Gliding.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? Getting to meet and work with people with such varied backgrounds and personalities.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? Putting myself in other people’s shoes.

Please list your hidden talent(s): Photography

How did you get your start in this career field? Working at a resort as a teenager was the only way I could afford to snowboard.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? It gives me the opportunity to do two things I love, teaching and snowboarding!

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? I’ve always wanted to learn to surf.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? How much these skills transfer into my other professions.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? It is possible to have a career that you love doing and hard work and determination pays off.

Please list your hidden talent(s): Juggling.

How did you get your start in this career field? I applied for a job at a small Ski Area after being in a job that I didn’t enjoy.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? My dad always encouraged me to “do what you love”.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Helicoptor backcountry snowboarding adventures.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? That I am actually a nerd about something- Snowsports Instruction.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? People learn in different ways. If you can flex your communication style to their preferences, you can teach anyone.

Please list your hidden talent(s): Whitewater canoeing, rafting, playing the drums, and gardening.

How did you get your start in this career field? Couldn’t afford a season pass.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? The culture of instructors has kept me around.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? Ride Japan.

What surprised you most about working in this industry? The vast information and nuances of the technical side.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? Anyone who wants to learn.

Please list your hidden talent(s): Motorcycle Coach and racer.

How did you get your start in this career field? I loved lessons as a kid and thought being an instructor would be cool! So I pursued it.

What inspired you to pursue the career you have today? Friends and mentors.

What’s something you’ve always wanted to try but haven’t yet? eFoil electric surfing – it seems perfect for land locked mountain folk!

What surprised you most about working in this industry? How nerdy instructing can be! It’s so cool.

What lesson are you most grateful for learning? I was quite shy and my public speaking was terrible when I first started teaching. Now I have more confidence and am much better at talking to groups of people (and am still trying to improve).

Please list your hidden talent(s): I’m still searching!

Hometown: Depends–either Salt Lake City, Utah or Fort Bridger, Wyoming– I have always spent summers in Wyoming and winters in Utah so both feel like home.

Sponsors: Burton, Hestra, RED, Anon

Favorite Run: Varies by snow condition, but something off the Cirque Traverse at Snowbird or the Alta Chutes at Jackson Hole

Favorite movie: Dodgeball

Playlist: Shuffle – I like to be surprised

Just Read: Hunger GamesTrilogy – saw the movie first and wanted to get some insight…

Coolest Place I’ve ever been: Too many to count – from local to Europe, South America, Australia, New Zealand

Average days on snow: Haven’t added it up lately but would guess something in the 175–200 days range, including early and late season training

Top Three off-snow activities:

1. Mountain biking

2. Spending time on my ranch–sure it’s work but I enjoy it

3. Travel

First skiing outfit: No clue – I was 4 years old. I do remember leather lace-up boots and safety straps. I do remember some of my first snowboarding clothing however – very day-glo…

Unusual Talent: Talking people into doing things they wouldn’t normally do.

Can usually be found: Working somewhere – either in Utah or Wyoming

Snowsports goal: To more closely unify the different divisions in certification. Any level of certification should have the same recognition no matter where the instructor received it.
